speaker: Doctor
text: What age is the infant, and how long have these episodes of stridor and wheezing been occurring?

speaker: Patient
text: I'm 10 months old, and my episodes of stridor and wheezing have been happening repeatedly for a while now.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed if these episodes are triggered by specific activities, such as crying, feeding, or exposure to certain environments?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, the wheezing gets worse when I cry or when I'm feeding. It also seems to happen more when my neck is bent.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you observed any other symptoms accompanying the stridor and wheezing, such as coughing, difficulty breathing, or changes in skin color?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any coughing or changes in my skin color, but sometimes I feel like it's hard to breathe during those episodes. I also occasionally vomit after I eat.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any patterns in the episodes, such as specific times of day or after certain foods?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't really noticed specific times of day, but it seems to happen more after I eat. Certain foods might make it worse, but I can't tell which ones.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any recent illnesses, such as colds or respiratory infections, prior to the onset of these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any colds or respiratory infections recently. I feel fine otherwise, just these episodes keep happening.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any difficulty swallowing or any signs of choking during feeding?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any difficulty swallowing, but sometimes it feels like I might choke a little when I'm eating. It can be a bit scary.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you been exposed to any allergens or irritants, such as smoke, pets, or strong odors, that might coincide with the episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't been around any smoke or pets, and there aren't any strong odors in my home. My parents keep things pretty clean.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any previous medical conditions or surgeries, particularly related to your throat or airway?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any medical conditions or surgeries before. I was born full term and everything was fine at birth.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight gain since these episodes began?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any big changes in my appetite, and I think I'm still gaining weight like I should. My mom says I'm eating well most of the time.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any episodes of reflux or spitting up more than usual, especially after feeding?

speaker: Patient
text: Sometimes I do spit up a little after I eat, and it feels like I might vomit. It doesn't happen all the time, but it can be a bit uncomfortable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any family history of allergies, asthma, or gastrointestinal issues that might be relevant to your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't know much about my family's health, but my parents haven't mentioned any allergies or asthma. No one in the family has had any gastrointestinal issues that I know of.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent changes in your feeding habits, such as switching to solid foods or trying new types of formula?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any big changes in my feeding habits. I'm still mostly on formula, but I've started trying some solid foods recently.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any episodes of excessive drooling or difficulty managing saliva during these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any excessive drooling, but sometimes it feels like I have a lot of saliva in my mouth during those episodes. It can be a bit hard to manage.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your breathing pattern when you are at rest, or does it only occur during these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: It only seems to happen during those episodes. When I'm at rest, my breathing feels normal.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any unusual sounds when breathing, such as a high-pitched noise or a gurgling sound, during these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, sometimes I make a high-pitched noise when I breathe during those episodes. It can be a bit alarming for my parents.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent dental issues or teething that might coincide with these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any dental issues, and I don't think I'm teething right now. My gums feel fine, and I haven't been fussy about it.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any episodes of choking or gagging during feeding that might suggest a swallowing issue?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't really choked or gagged during feeding, but sometimes it feels like I might if I'm not careful. It can be a little scary when that happens.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent changes in your environment, such as moving to a new home or changes in household members that could affect your exposure to allergens?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't moved to a new home or had any changes in my household. Everything has been pretty much the same at home with my parents around.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any episodes of wheezing or stridor during sleep, or does it only occur while awake?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any wheezing or stridor during sleep. It only seems to happen when I'm awake, especially when I'm crying or feeding.

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on your symptoms and the information you've provided, it sounds like you may be experiencing episodes related to a condition called laryngomalacia, which is common in infants. However, to confirm this, I would like to REQUEST TEST: Flexible_Laryngoscopy to visualize your airway.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Maximum inferences reached

speaker: Patient
text: I feel a bit worried about these episodes. They can be really scary for me and my parents.
